title: 109_hr4263
content: The Windfall Profits and Consumer Assistance Act of 2005 includes a Windfall Profits Tax on crude oil. This tax is imposed under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Windfall Profits and Consumer Assistance Act of 2005 imposes an excise tax on crude oil producers based on the excess of windfall profit over qualified investment. The tax is paid by the producer of the taxable crude oil. The Windfall Profits and Consumer Assistance Act of 2005 defines windfall profit as the excess of the removal price of taxable crude oil over the adjusted base price. The removal price is determined based on the sale amount, with specific rules for related party sales and oil removed before sale. The Windfall Profits and Consumer Assistance Act of 2005 defines windfall profit as the excess of the removal price of taxable crude oil over the adjusted base price, which is $40 for each barrel of crude oil plus an additional amount. The removal price is determined based on specific rules for related party sales and oil removed before sale. The Windfall Profits and Consumer Assistance Act of 2005 defines windfall profit as the excess of the removal price of taxable crude oil over the adjusted base price, which is $40 for each barrel of crude oil plus an additional amount determined by an inflation adjustment. The inflation adjustment is calculated based on the percentage difference in the implicit price deflator for the gross national product between the current year and the base year of 2005. The first revision of the price deflator is used for determining qualified investments, which include various types of expenses such as section 263(c) costs, qualified refinery property, qualified facilities, and alcohol production facilities for fuel. The term 'section 263(c) costs' refers to intangible drilling and development costs that can be deducted as expenses, excluding costs for drilling nonproductive wells. "SEC. 5898. SPECIAL RULES AND DEFINITIONS." The Secretary will establish rules for withholding and depositing the tax on taxable crude oil. Taxpayers must maintain records, submit returns, and provide information as required. The Secretary will outline the filing process for the tax return. Definitions include 'producer' as the economic interest holder of crude oil and 'crude oil' broadly defined. The term 'crude oil' includes condensates and natural gasoline. Newly discovered oil is excluded, except for oil produced from a well drilled on proven oil or gas property after a certain date. A 'barrel' is defined as 42 US gallons. The Secretary can adjust the removal price of oil to reflect fair market value. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the chapter's purposes. This section will not apply to taxable crude oil removed after 3 years from enactment. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. Chapter 56 of the Internal Revenue Code applies to crude oil removed after the enactment date. Transitional rules will be in place until December 31, 2005. The Secretary will prescribe rules for the administration of chapter 56. Additionally, a Consumer Energy Assistance Trust Fund is established. Consumer Energy Assistance Trust Fund established under SEC. 9511 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Consumer Energy Assistance Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States under SEC. 9511, with appropriations from taxes received under chapter 56 for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Act of 1981. SEC. 4. ENERGY CONSUMER REBATE. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to add a new section for Energy Consumer Rebate under Subchapter B of chapter 65. The text discusses the general rule for individuals making payments against the tax imposed by chapter 1 for taxable years after December 31, 2005. It outlines the criteria for determining the liability for tax for any taxable year. The text outlines the criteria for determining the taxpayer's social security taxes for the taxable year, taking into account applicable amounts determined by the Secretary based on the number of taxpayers and Treasury revenues. The payment provided by this section is deemed made on a specified date. The payment provided by this section is deemed made on February 1 of the calendar year, and the Secretary must remit it to each taxpayer within 30 days. Certain persons, such as those eligible for a deduction under section 151 or nonresident alien individuals, are not eligible for this payment. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions from the Windfall Profits and Consumer Assistance Act of 2005. Additionally, a new item is added to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65. Sec. 6430. Energy consumer rebate. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.
